custom_item_1.info: There are several services that should be considered for disabling. Depending on your enterprise security structure, the state of any service depends on where the service is deployed and how deep it is in your infrastructure.

custom_item_20.description: 2.1 Enable Secure Admin Access - 'ssh.access is not unlimited'

custom_item_21.description: 2.1 Enable Secure Admin Access - 'ssh.access has been configured'
custom_item_21.info: NetApp recommends that you configure and enable SecureAdmin immediately after initially setting up Data ONTAP. Best practice suggesting enabling SSH and SSL encryption for secure administration of the NetApp storage system.
custom_item_21.solution: Configure ssh.access to include only approved hosts or IP ranges

custom_item_22.info: NetApp recommends that you configure and enable SecureAdmin immediately after initially setting up Data ONTAP. Best practice suggesting enabling SSH and SSL encryption for secure administration of the NetApp storage system.

custom_item_23.info: NetApp recommends that you configure and enable SecureAdmin immediately after initially setting up Data ONTAP. Best practice suggesting enabling SSH and SSL encryption for secure administration of the NetApp storage system.

custom_item_26.info: NetApp recommends that you configure and enable SecureAdmin immediately after initially setting up Data ONTAP. Best practice suggesting enabling SSH and SSL encryption for secure administration of the NetApp storage system.
custom_item_26.solution: Enable telenet.distinct.enable to make the ssh and console separate user environments

custom_item_27.info: NetApp recommends that you configure and enable SecureAdmin immediately after initially setting up Data ONTAP. Best practice suggesting enabling SSH and SSL encryption for secure administration of the NetApp storage system.
custom_item_27.solution: Enable automatic disconnect of inactive SSH Interactive sessions

custom_item_28.info: NetApp recommends that you configure and enable SecureAdmin immediately after initially setting up Data ONTAP. Best practice suggesting enabling SSH and SSL encryption for secure administration of the NetApp storage system.
custom_item_28.solution: Enable automatic disconnect of inactive SSH Interactive sessions

custom_item_29.info: By default FilerView is enabled on port 80, and this will pass all authentications in clear text. NetApp recommends that the ssl protocol be utilized for Web communication to the storage system for administrative functions.
custom_item_29.solution: Configure the HTTP idle connection timeout to 300 seconds or less

custom_item_30.info: The root account needs to be disabled in order to meet many, if not all, of the GRC standards. You will need to create a new administrative account prior to disabling root. Other functions that use this account such as NDMP and ndmpcopy might be affected. It will be necessary to use a different account for these functions.

custom_item_31.info: By default, telnet, RIPv1, rsh, and webdav are enabled. If these services are not required in your infrastructure, NetApp recommends that they be disabled.
custom_item_31.solution: Disable rsh access or limit it to only known, trusted hosts

custom_item_32.info: By default, telnet, RIPv1, rsh, and webdav are enabled. If these services are not required in your infrastructure, NetApp recommends that they be disabled.
custom_item_32.solution: Disable telnet access or limit it to only known, trusted hosts

custom_item_33.info: Requiring high quality passwords decreases the opportunity for unauthorized access.
custom_item_33.solution: Enable password properties application to all acounts

custom_item_34.info: Requiring high quality passwords decreases the opportunity for unauthorized access.
custom_item_34.solution: Limit the minimum password length to 8 characters or more

custom_item_35.info: Requiring high quality passwords decreases the opportunity for unauthorized access.
custom_item_35.solution: Limit the maximum password length to 14 characters or more

custom_item_36.info: Requiring high quality passwords decreases the opportunity for unauthorized access.
custom_item_36.solution: Limit the required minimum number of alphabetic characters to at least 2

custom_item_37.info: Requiring high quality passwords decreases the opportunity for unauthorized access.
custom_item_37.solution: Limit the required minimum number of numeric characters to at least 1

custom_item_38.info: Requiring high quality passwords decreases the opportunity for unauthorized access.
custom_item_38.solution: Limit the required minimum number of special characters to at least 1

custom_item_39.info: Requiring high quality passwords decreases the opportunity for unauthorized access.
custom_item_39.solution: Limit the required password history to at least 6

custom_item_40.info: Requiring high quality passwords decreases the opportunity for unauthorized access.
custom_item_40.solution: Limit the number of bad passwords before account lockout to 6 or less

custom_item_41.info: Requiring high quality passwords decreases the opportunity for unauthorized access.
custom_item_41.solution: Require users to change their password at their first login

custom_item_42.info: The autologout capability is required by several security standards. In Data ONTAP these requirements can be met by setting the timeout times in the various interfaces. If the timeouts are enabled, the session will be terminated and will require reauthentication.
custom_item_42.solution: Limit the console idle timeout to 5 minutes or less

custom_item_43.info: The autologout capability is required by several security standards. In Data ONTAP these requirements can be met by setting the timeout times in the various interfaces. If the timeouts are enabled, the session will be terminated and will require reauthentication.
custom_item_43.solution: Enable the autologout of the console when the idle timeout has been reached

custom_item_44.info: The autologout capability is required by several security standards. In Data ONTAP these requirements can be met by setting the timeout times in the various interfaces. If the timeouts are enabled, the session will be terminated and will require reauthentication.
custom_item_44.solution: Limit the SSH 'orphan' timeout to 300 or less

custom_item_45.info: Data ONTAP provides logging capabilities for many functions within the base operating system as well as many of the protocols; licensed services provide their own logging. The base logging of Data ONTAP includes an audit log and a messages log.

custom_item_46.info: Data ONTAP provides logging capabilities for many functions within the base operating system as well as many of the protocols; licensed services provide their own logging. The base logging of Data ONTAP includes an audit log and a messages log.
custom_item_46.solution: Limit the audit max file size

custom_item_47.info: Because NFS, CIFS, iSCSI, and administrative clients access Data ONTAP over TCP/IP networks, it is important to configure the networking on the NetApp storage system in a secure fashion. The most relevant documentation for this purpose is the 'Data ONTAP Network Management Guide.'

custom_item_48.info: Because NFS, CIFS, iSCSI, and administrative clients access Data ONTAP over TCP/IP networks, it is important to configure the networking on the NetApp storage system in a secure fashion. The most relevant documentation for this purpose is the 'Data ONTAP Network Management Guide.'

custom_item_49.info: Because NFS, CIFS, iSCSI, and administrative clients access Data ONTAP over TCP/IP networks, it is important to configure the networking on the NetApp storage system in a secure fashion. The most relevant documentation for this purpose is the 'Data ONTAP Network Management Guide.'
custom_item_49.solution: Disable IP match any interface address

custom_item_50.info: Because NFS, CIFS, iSCSI, and administrative clients access Data ONTAP over TCP/IP networks, it is important to configure the networking on the NetApp storage system in a secure fashion. The most relevant documentation for this purpose is the 'Data ONTAP Network Management Guide.'
custom_item_50.solution: Set the IP ping throttle alarm interval to 15 minutes or greater

custom_item_51.info: Because NFS, CIFS, iSCSI, and administrative clients access Data ONTAP over TCP/IP networks, it is important to configure the networking on the NetApp storage system in a secure fashion. The most relevant documentation for this purpose is the 'Data ONTAP Network Management Guide.'
custom_item_51.solution: Set the IP ping throttle drop level to 100 or less

custom_item_52.description: 2.8 Protocol Access Controls - 'interface.blocked.cifs is not blank'
custom_item_52.info: Protocol blocking enables you to specifically disable several protocols by physical interface, providing additional flexibility when designing secure storage systems. For example, NFS could be blocked on a pair of interfaces, so that NFS requests to either of these interfaces are ignored.
custom_item_52.solution: Block the CIFS protocol on unneeded interfaces

custom_item_65.description: 2.8 Protocol Access Controls - 'rsh.access has been configured'
custom_item_65.info: Data ONTAP allows the configuration of filters for the following protocols: RSH, telnet, SSH, HTTP, SNMP, NDMP, SnapMirror, and SnapVault. The filters can specify host names, IP addresses, IP subnets, or interface names, which are either allowed or disallowed for each protocol. Each application then uses the filter on the listening socket to control access. In conjunction with disabling insecure protocols, this allows fine-grained control of access from limited areas. NetApp recommends as a best practice that you configure protocol access filters for any administrative protocol that is enabled on the NetApp storage system.
custom_item_65.solution: Configure rsh to allow connections only from known trusted hosts

custom_item_66.description: 2.8 Protocol Access Controls - 'telnet.access has been configured'

Each application then uses the filter on the listening socket to control access. In conjunction with disabling insecure protocols, this allows fine-grained control of access from limited areas. NetApp recommends as a best practice that you configure protocol access filters for any administrative protocol that is enabled on the NetApp storage system.
custom_item_66.solution: Configure telnet to allow connections only from known trusted hosts

custom_item_69.description: 3.2 Data ONTAP (Software) Mgmt - 'httpd.admin.access has been configured'
custom_item_69.info: NOTE: Update {HTTP_ADMIN_ACCESS} with the appropriate value for the local environment
custom_item_69.solution: Configure httpd.admin.access to restricts HTTP access to System Manager

custom_item_70.info: System Manager is a graphical management interface that enables you to manage most storage system functions through a telnet session, the rsh command, or scripts or configuration files rather than by entering commands at the console. You can also use System Manager to view information about the storage system; its physical storage units, such as adapters, disks, and RAID groups; and its data storage units, such as aggregates, volumes, and LUNs.
custom_item_70.solution: Disable the use of /etc/hosts.equiv for administrative HTTP authentication. If enabled, the authentication of administrative HTTP (for APIs) will use the contents of /etc/hosts.equiv to allow access to the storage controller without the need to provide a password.

custom_item_71.info: System Manager is a graphical management interface that enables you to manage most storage system functions through a telnet session, the rsh command, or scripts or configuration files rather than by entering commands at the console. You can also use System Manager to view information about the storage system; its physical storage units, such as adapters, disks, and RAID groups; and its data storage units, such as aggregates, volumes, and LUNs.

custom_item_72.info: MultiStore enables you to partition the storage and network resources of a single storage system so that it appears as multiple storage systems on the network. MultiStore is optional software that is available by license for Data ONTAP.

custom_item_73.info: SnapMirror is a feature of Data ONTAP that enables you to replicate data. SnapMirror enables you to replicate data from specified source volumes or qtrees to specified destination volumes or qtrees, respectively.

custom_item_76.info: SnapMirror is a feature of Data ONTAP that enables you to replicate data. SnapMirror enables you to replicate data from specified source volumes or qtrees to specified destination volumes or qtrees, respectively.
custom_item_76.solution:
Configure the snapmirror.access option to limit access to SnapMirror to known, trusted hosts

          Additional information: http://media.netapp.com/documents/TR-3446.pdf

custom_item_77.info: SnapMirror is a feature of Data ONTAP that enables you to replicate data. SnapMirror enables you to replicate data from specified source volumes or qtrees to specified destination volumes or qtrees, respectively.

custom_item_78.info: SnapMirror is a feature of Data ONTAP that enables you to replicate data. SnapMirror enables you to replicate data from specified source volumes or qtrees to specified destination volumes or qtrees, respectively.
custom_item_78.solution:
Enable global network throttling of SnapMirror and SnapVault transfers

      Additional information: http://media.netapp.com/documents/TR-3446.pdf

custom_item_79.info: SnapMirror is a feature of Data ONTAP that enables you to replicate data. SnapMirror enables you to replicate data from specified source volumes or qtrees to specified destination volumes or qtrees, respectively.
custom_item_79.solution:
On the destination system, specify the maximum total bandwidth used by all incoming SnapMirror and SnapVault transfers (specified in kilobytes/sec)

      Additional information: http://media.netapp.com/documents/TR-3446.pdf

custom_item_80.info: SnapMirror is a feature of Data ONTAP that enables you to replicate data. SnapMirror enables you to replicate data from specified source volumes or qtrees to specified destination volumes or qtrees, respectively.
custom_item_80.solution:
On the source system, specify the maximum total bandwidth used by all incoming SnapMirror and SnapVault transfers (specified in kilobytes/sec)

      Additional information: http://media.netapp.com/documents/TR-3446.pdf

custom_item_81.info: SnapVault leverages disk-based backup and block-level incremental backups for reliable, low-overhead backup and recovery suitable for any environment. SnapVault enables data stored on multiple systems to be backed up to a central secondary system quickly and efficiently as read-only Snapshot copies.

custom_item_83.info: SnapVault leverages disk-based backup and block-level incremental backups for reliable, low-overhead backup and recovery suitable for any environment. SnapVault enables data stored on multiple systems to be backed up to a central secondary system quickly and efficiently as read-only Snapshot copies.
custom_item_83.solution:
Configure the snapvault.access option to limit acces to SnapVault to known, trusted hosts

      Additional information: http://media.netapp.com/documents/TR-3446.pdf

custom_item_84.info: SnapVault leverages disk-based backup and block-level incremental backups for reliable, low-overhead backup and recovery suitable for any environment. SnapVault enables data stored on multiple systems to be backed up to a central secondary system quickly and efficiently as read-only Snapshot copies.
custom_item_84.solution:
Configure the snapvault.snapshot_for_dr_backup appropriately for the required transfer schedule

      Additional information: http://media.netapp.com/documents/TR-3446.pdf

custom_item_85.info: SnapVault leverages disk-based backup and block-level incremental backups for reliable, low-overhead backup and recovery suitable for any environment. SnapVault enables data stored on multiple systems to be backed up to a central secondary system quickly and efficiently as read-only Snapshot copies.
custom_item_85.solution:
Enable snapvault.preservesnap to globally preserve Snapshot copies from rolling off.

      Additional information: http://media.netapp.com/documents/TR-3446.pdf

custom_item_86.info: CIFS is a file-sharing protocol intended to provide an open cross-platform mechanism for client systems to request file services from server systems over a network. It is based on the standard Server Message Block (SMB) protocol widely in use by personal computers and workstations running a wide variety of operating systems.

custom_item_88.info: NetApp recommends the use of security features in IP storage protocols to secure client access

custom_item_89.info: CIFS is a file-sharing protocol intended to provide an open cross-platform mechanism for client systems to request file services from server systems over a network. It is based on the standard Server Message Block (SMB) protocol widely in use by personal computers and workstations running a wide variety of operating systems.
custom_item_89.solution:
Enable SMB signing for SMB 2.0 protocol

      Additional information: http://media.netapp.com/documents/TR-3367.pdf

custom_item_90.info: CIFS is a file-sharing protocol intended to provide an open cross-platform mechanism for client systems to request file services from server systems over a network. custom_item_119.info: CIFS is a file-sharing protocol intended to provide an open cross-platform mechanism for client systems to request file services from server systems over a network. It is based on the standard Server Message Block (SMB) protocol widely in use by personal computers and workstations running a wide variety of operating systems.
custom_item_119.solution:
Enable SMB 2.0 client capability on the storage system. When this option is enabled, NetApp system-initiated connections to Windows domain controllers attempt to use the SMB 2.0 protocol.

      Additional information: http://media.netapp.com/documents/TR-3595.pdf

custom_item_120.info: CIFS is a file-sharing protocol intended to provide an open cross-platform mechanism for client systems to request file services from server systems over a network. It is based on the standard Server Message Block (SMB) protocol widely in use by personal computers and workstations running a wide variety of operating systems.
custom_item_120.solution:
Enable the durable handle functionality for SMB 2.0 clients. If this option is enabled, the open files from a client are preserved when the client gets disconnected from the NetApp system.

      Additional information: http://media.netapp.com/documents/TR-3595.pdf

Setting this option is set to the null string. Windows users who are not mapped to a UNIX user are not allowed to log in.

custom_item_139.info: Network File System (NFS) is one of the most popular distributed file system protocols that allows a client computer to access files on shared storage over the network. NFS version 4 (NFSv4) is an improved version of NFS protocol versions 2 and 3.

custom_item_140.info: Network File System (NFS) is one of the most popular distributed file system protocols that allows a client computer to access files on shared storage over the network. NFS version 4 (NFSv4) is an improved version of NFS protocol versions 2 and 3.

          Additional information: http://media.netapp.com/documents/TR-3580.pdf

custom_item_142.info: Network File System (NFS) is one of the most popular distributed file system protocols that allows a client computer to access files on shared storage over the network. NFS version 4 (NFSv4) is an improved version of NFS protocol versions 2 and 3.

custom_item_143.info: Network File System (NFS) is one of the most popular distributed file system protocols that allows a client computer to access files on shared storage over the network. NFS version 4 (NFSv4) is an improved version of NFS protocol versions 2 and 3.
